faqs.question: What is an MD course? What should I do to pursue MD course?
faqs.answer: MD full form is Doctor of Medicine. In India, the MD course lasts roughly two years and includes a variety of specialisations. The Doctor of Medicine subject is varied and adaptable to provide students with a suitable education. The spread of the pandemic and the expansion of the healthcare infrastructure have increased the demand for MD Medicine experts. The healthcare sector will expand to become a big employer in the next years. Good work options, including those as clinical practitioners and teachers, are provided by the medical job scope in India .

faqs.question: Why should I choose MD course?
faqs.answer: While there is a slight bias in favour of specialisations among MDs , General Medicine nevertheless holds its own. Its popularity has increased for a number of valid reasons. Here is a list of arguments that can persuade you to choose General Medicine if you are still debating it. General Medicine has numerous applications in the field of Medicine, in contrast to specialists who concentrate on just one particular patient demography. It can act as a gateway to many other medical specialities thanks to its wide scope of interest. According to numerous reports, there is a growing need for general practitioners.

faqs.question: What are the merits and demerits of doing an MD course in general medicine?
faqs.answer: General medicine, alias internal medicine, comes with its set of merits and demerits in choosing an MD . Merits: Scope of Knowledge: An MD in general medicine confers knowledge on a wide variety of medical conditions, diagnostic techniques, and treating options in the different organ systems. Versatility: A general medicine MD is trained in the diagnosis and management of a wide range of disorders and diseases; hence, they are versatile doctors in treating a broad spectrum of the needs of patients. Foundational to Specialization: An MD in general medicine thus will be a good foundation for one who would later like to specialize in one area of medicine. Holistic Approach: Internal medicine is concerned with the 'holistic approach' while undertaking patient care. It encompasses the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of several diseases and disorders in the adult patient population. Career Opportunities: Students attaining an MD in general medicine have a wide scope of career opportunities, from primary care practice to hospitalists, from academic medicine and research fields to healthcare administration. Demerits: Heavy Workload: Residencies in internal medicine largely go in correlation with heavy work hours and loaded patient caseloads, predisposing residents and practitioners to burnout. Broad Scope of Practice: Though the broad scope within Internal Medicine may be viewed as a merit, this is sometimes considered a demerit for those practitioners who get overwhelmed by the depth of knowledge required in various medical conditions. Limited Specialization: Though the general medicine course imparts broad-based fundamentals, it lacks the in-depth specialization offered by other medical specialities with a narrower scope. Complex Patients: The internal medicine physician tends to deal with complex cases medically, hence intellectually stimulating but emotionally tiring.

faqs.question: Can I pursue MD course after my MBBS?
faqs.answer: Yes, candidates who have completed the MBBS are eligible for an MD , which is a post-graduate degree. It is comparable to a doctorate in India and the UK. Similarly, MS is a post-graduate degree available to individuals in the medical industry. Candidates must pass the NEET-PG entrance exam if they want to pursue an MS , MD, or medical diploma. Further, the eligibility criteria required to pursue MD is given below: Candidates must have earned their MBBS from an accredited institution. He or she ought to have received at least a 50% on the MBBS. Candidates must have finished a one-year required internship.

faqs.question: Can a Pharma.D student do MD course in general medicine?
faqs.answer: No, candidates cannot pursue MD in general medicine after Pharm D. To get eligible for the above course candidates must have completed MBBS/BAMS with a minimum aggregate score of 50%, with a 1-year compulsory internship. Thanks.

faqs.question: Can I do MD course in Medical without MBBS?
faqs.answer: No, candidates cannot do MD medicine without MBBS . An MBBS degree from any college recognised by the MCI is required for both the MS and MD programmes in India. For candidates to pursue a specialisation in MD or MS, they must also have a NEET score or clearance from any other exam. Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery is the full form of MBBS. MBBS is an undergraduate programme for people who desire to pursue their ambition of becoming doctors. It is a medical Science professional degree. The MBBS programme consists of five years of study in 19 medical courses, followed by six months of internship. The NEET is used to assess MBBS admission eligibility. Students must be over the age of 17 and have finished Class 12 with Physics, Chemistry, and Biology as compulsory subjects to be eligible for the NEET. Students will be qualified as medical practitioners or doctors after completing the MBBS and receiving the degree.

faqs.question: Can I do MD after 12th?
faqs.answer: No, you cannot pursue MD directly after 12th. MD is a PG medical degree that can only be pursued after completing an MBBS (Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery). After your 12th with PCB subjects, you must clear NEET-UG, complete the 5.5-year MBBS course, and then qualify for NEET-PG to apply for MD in your chosen specialization.

faqs.question: Is a career in MD course a worthwhile one?
faqs.answer: Due to the financial opportunities it offers, the MD in General Medicine has historically been one of the most sought-after programmes in the Medical field. The spectrum of its professional ramifications includes anything from working in the public or commercial sector to pursuing advanced research initiatives in academia. Successful MD General Medicine postgraduates may pursue an MPhil or PhD to advance their academic careers and enter the teaching profession. They are well-paid employees in the public and commercial sectors in organisations like railroads, State PSCs, State medical colleges, research and educational institutions, military services, biomedical enterprises, pharmaceutical manufacturers, etc. after choosing this career.

faqs.question: What is the average package for MD course in general medicine?
faqs.answer: Hi, MD General Medicine salary in India ranges between INR 1.0 Lacs to INR36.0 Lacs with an average annual salary of INR 12.0 Lacs.

faqs.question: Do MD Medicine doctors do surgery?
faqs.answer: MD Medicine doctors, also known as medical doctors, have the authority to perform surgeries. These professionals have completed Medical school and have earned a degree in Medicine. MD Medicine graduates have undergone rigorous training to acquire the knowledge and skills necessary to perform various medical procedures, including surgical operations.

faqs.question: Who earns more MD Medicine or MS?
faqs.answer: The average salary of an MD medicine graduate is 12 LPA while that of an MS graduate is 17.7 LPA. Further, the earning potential of individuals with a Doctor of Medicine (MD) degree versus those with a Master of Surgery (MS) degree in India can vary based on several factors, including the specific medical speciality, years of experience, geographic location, and the type of healthcare institution. Both MD and MS degrees represent postgraduate medical qualifications, but they typically lead to different career paths.

faqs.question: Is USA MD course equal to MBBS?

blocks.value: While both the MD degree in the United States and the MBBS degree in India represent qualifications for medical practitioners, they are earned through different educational systems and processes. Therefore, they are not directly equivalent, and there are important distinctions between the two.

It's essential to understand that the comparison between the two qualifications involves multiple factors, including the structure of medical education, postgraduate training, and the regulatory frameworks in each country. While both the MD and MBBS degrees signify that an individual has completed the required medical education, they are part of distinct systems with their own set of requirements and standards.

faqs.question: How do doctors end up choosing a super specialty after doing MD course?

blocks.value: Choosing a super-speciality after completing an MD in Medicine is a crucial decision that depends on various factors, including personal interests, aptitudes, career goals, and the opportunities available.
Here is a general overview of the process doctors often follow to select a super-specialty:

value: Self-Assessment and Interests: Doctors often begin by reflecting on their interests, strengths, and passions within the field of medicine.
Clinical Exposure: During the MD in Medicine program, doctors gain exposure to various medical specialities through clinical rotations.
Mentorship and Guidance: Seeking guidance from mentors, senior physicians, or faculty members can be valuable.

Research and Continuing Education: Engaging in research projects or continuing education programs related to specific medical disciplines can deepen knowledge and help in making informed decisions about a super-speciality.
Job Opportunities and Demand: Assessing the job market and demand for different specialities in your preferred location or region is important.

faqs.question: What is the scope of research in MD course?

blocks.value: MD graduates have excellent opportunities in clinical, translational, and public health research. Many medical colleges and institutions offer dedicated research departments and fellowships.

You can engage in clinical trials, epidemiological studies, or even policy research in health organizations. With growing support from ICMR, WHO, and AIIMS-like institutes, MD professionals can build strong research-based careers in both India and abroad.

faqs.question: Can I pursue MD course through distance or online mode?

blocks.value: No, the MD course in India cannot be pursued via distance or online mode. It is a full-time, practical-intensive postgraduate programme regulated by the National Medical Commission (NMC).

It involves hospital rotations, clinical practice, and hands-on training under supervision. Any MD degree pursued via non-traditional modes will not be recognised or valid for medical practice or employment in India.

faqs.question: Can I apply for a teaching post in medical colleges after an MD course?

blocks.value: Yes, after completing your MD , you are eligible to apply for teaching positions such as Assistant Professor or Lecturer in medical colleges. Many MD graduates start their careers in academia, contributing to both teaching and clinical services. Further experience, research publications, and seniority can lead to promotions as Associate Professor or Professor in reputed medical institutions.

faqs.question: Can I open a hospital or clinic after completing an MD course?

blocks.value: Yes, you can open a clinic or nursing home after completing your MD , provided you meet the legal and infrastructural guidelines set by the local health authorities.

An MD degree also strengthens your credibility as a specialist. While opening a full-scale hospital may require partnerships, infrastructure, and licenses, starting your own specialty clinic is a common and viable option.

faqs.question: What is the starting salary range for MD course professionals in India?

blocks.value: MD graduates in India typically start with salaries ranging from INR 70,000 to INR 1.5 Lacs per month, depending on their specialty, location, and type of institution.

Government hospitals and reputed private chains may offer higher packages. Over time, with clinical experience or private practice, earnings can grow significantly, especially in high-demand fields like radiology, dermatology, or internal medicine.

faqs.question: Can MD course doctors work in research organizations or pharmaceutical companies?

blocks.value: Yes, MD doctors can work in clinical research, medical affairs, or pharmacovigilance roles in pharmaceutical companies and research organizations. They contribute to clinical trials, drug development, safety monitoring, and scientific writing. Organizations like ICMR, WHO, and global pharma giants like Pfizer or Novartis actively hire MDs for medically-driven research roles and advisory positions.

faqs.question: Is pursuing a PhD after an MD course a good option for academic careers?

blocks.value: Yes, pursuing a PhD after MD is a great option for those interested in academic medicine and research. It deepens your expertise in a focused area and strengthens your credentials for teaching, publishing, and leading projects. Many medical colleges and universities in India and abroad encourage PhD-qualified doctors for senior academic and research leadership roles. It's especially ideal for those aiming for a career in medical education and innovation.

blocks.value: Frequently Asked Questions Regarding MD Subjects
Q: What is the scope of an MD?

A: An MD is a postgraduate professional program me meant to enable qualified applicants to become masters in the sector of their choice. This program me makes candidates competent and cognisable individuals in their associated area of study.
Q: Do I need an MD to practise medicine?
A: No, MBBS-holders may practise medicine. MD candidates may specialise in any medical discipline (Doctor of Medicine).
Q: How long does an MD course take?
A: In India, MD may be completed in three years.
Q: What are the entrance exams for MD?
A: MD applicants may take NEET-PG, JIPMER PG, AIIMS PG, etc.
Q: What are MD's employment prospects?
A: MD graduates may work as medical pathologists, professors, bacteriologists, anesthesiologists, and general practitioners.
Q: What is the average cost of an MD course?
A: Depending on the university, the annual cost for an MD might vary from INR 1,00,000 to INR 10,00,000.
Q: Is an internship required for admission to an MD programme?
A: Entrance into the MD programme requires the completion of a one-year internship.
Q: Is it possible for me to get my doctorate while working full time?
A: Only full-time MDs are eligible for the program me . As a result, MD programmes don't have a distance learning option .
Q: How many types of MD courses are there?
A: There are 68 postgraduate courses as part of the MD programme.
Q: After MBBS, which MD is the most qualified to practise?
A: MD in Anatomy or Doctor of Medicine after MBBS is recommended for people who desire to work in the medical field, either in a hospital or medical school.

MBBS is a 5.5-year undergraduate degree course that candidates can pursue after completing Class 12 (Science stream) and typically includes a one-year internship. On the other hand, MD is a 3-year postgraduate degree course that can be pursued after MBBS degree.

MBBS is the foundational medical degree in India, after which, candidates are eligible to practice as general physicians . MD , however, is a specialised PG course that allows doctors to gain expertise in a particular medical field . Many doctors pursue MD to become specialists in a specific area of medicine and offer advanced healthcare services to patients.

What is MBBS?

MBBS is an undergraduate degree program in India that is equivalent to a Medical degree in many other countries. It is typically a 5.5-year program (including a one-year internship), which candidates can opt for after completing Class 12 with Science (Physics, Chemistry and Biology) subjects.

The curriculum of MBBS includes basic medical sciences, clinical subjects, and practical training in various medical specialities. MBBS curriculum provides a broad foundation in medicine and clinical skills. Graduates with an MBBS course in India are commonly referred to as ‘Doctors or ‘Medical Practitioners’. After completing MBBS, individuals can work as general practitioners or pursue postgraduate education (MD/MS) to specialize in a particular medical field.
What is MD?

MD is a postgraduate medical degree in India that provides specialized training in a specific medical speciality or subspecialty. To pursue MD in India, individuals typically need to complete their MBBS degree and qualify in the National Eligibility cum Entrance Test for Postgraduate (NEET-PG) examination. MD programs in India usually last for 3 years and are available in various specialities such as Internal Medicine, Surgery, Paediatrics, Radiology , Dermatology , etc.

MD graduates in India are considered specialists in their chosen field and are eligible to practice as specialised physicians. They can work in hospitals, clinics, research institutions, or private practice. After completing MD, some doctors may choose to pursue further super-specialisation through DM (Doctorate of Medicine) or DNB (Diplomate of National Board) courses.

MD vs MBBS FAQs
Q. Which degree is better MD or MBBS?
A. The choice between an MD (Doctor of Medicine) and an MBBS (Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery) depends on the country and the specific career goals of the individual.

Neither MD nor MBBS is inherently better than the other; it depends on one’s career goals and where one plans to practice Medicine. Candidates should consider factors such as the length of education, licensing requirements, and their desired specialization when making their decision.
Additionally, it's important to research the specific programs and institutions offering these degrees to ensure they align with their career aspirations.
Q. Who earns more MBBS or MD?
A. The salary and earning potential of an individual with an MBBS versus an MD can vary significantly depending on several factors .
However, MDs often have more opportunities for specialisation and may, therefore, have the potential for higher earnings, especially if they become specialists in high-demand fields.

Both MBBS and MD degrees can lead to successful and well-compensated careers in Medicine, depending on individual circumstances and career choices. It's essential to consider the affecting factors and conduct research specific to one’s location and career goals when assessing earning potential in the medical field. The factors that may affect the earnings of MBBS and MD graduates are as follows:
Q. Can MD doctors do surgery?
A. In India, doctors with MD course cannot perform surgery. For that, they must pursue surgical practice.

After completing the MBBS program, Indian doctors have the option to pursue postgraduate training in various medical specialities. They can choose to do an MD (Doctor of Medicine) or MS (Master of Surgery) program, which are equivalent to postgraduate medical degrees. MS is particularly focused on surgical specialities. Alternatively, doctors can opt for the Diplomate of National Board (DNB) program in their chosen speciality.
Q. Is MD compulsory after MBBS?

A. No, pursuing an MD degree is not compulsory after completing an MBBS degree. In India, an MBBS degree is a recognized medical qualification that allows individuals to practice medicine as general practitioners or pursue various medical specialities without obtaining an MD.

However, many doctors in India choose to pursue postgraduate education after MBBS. Postgraduate degrees like MD offer specialization in specific medical fields such as internal medicine, paediatrics, dermatology, surgery, etc. These programs provide in-depth knowledge and training in a particular area of medicine.

While postgraduate education, including MD programs, is a common path for doctors in India, it is not mandatory. Doctors can choose to practice as general practitioners with an MBBS degree or pursue other avenues within the medical field based on their career goals and interests. The decision to pursue further education should align with one's career aspirations and the specific demands of their chosen medical speciality.
Q. What is the salary difference between MBBS and MD?

A. The salary difference between an MBBS and an MD can vary significantly based on several factors, including the country in which candidates practice, specialization, level of experience, and the specific healthcare facility or organization.

It's important to note that an MBBS is typically an undergraduate medical degree, while an MD is a postgraduate degree that comes after completing the MBBS. MD programs often involve more specialised training and may lead to higher-paying opportunities, but this can vary by country and speciality.
The average MBBS salary is INR 6 LPA, while, the average MD salary can go up to INR 8.6 LPA.
Q. Is MBBS done from India equivalent to MD in USA?
A. Yes, MBBS done from India is equivalent to MD in USA. Since India belongs to one of the Commonwealth Nations, Indian MBBS can be considered equal to MD in USA.

However, the specific requirements and pathways for individuals with foreign medical degrees to obtain licensure in the United States can vary by state and may change over time. Therefore, it's essential to consult with the relevant licensing authorities and organizations, such as the Educational Commission for Foreign Medical Graduates (ECFMG), for the most up-to-date information and guidance on how to pursue a medical career in the United States with an MBBS degree from India.

All India Institute of Medical Sciences, popularly known as AIIMS is one of the most sought-after medical colleges in India. Medical aspirants from not just India but across the world aspire to get through one of the AIIMS campuses, especially the oldest and top-ranked ones. Aspirants often ask, how many AIIMS in India are there. At present, there are 26 AIIMS colleges in India out of which the majority are functional, and the rest are yet to be operational. Some of the AIIMS colleges in India have started to offer classes, but are under construction. AIIMS Vijaypur, Jammu, has launched a BSc Nursing course from the academic year 2025 onwards.

AIIMS used to conduct its own MBBS entrance exam, which was scrapped in 2019 and the admission is now conducted through the National Eligibility Entrance Test (NEET) from the academic year 2021-22. On the other hand, INI CET is the qualifying exam for admission to post-graduate courses at AIIMS and INI SS exam is held for admission to Super Speciality courses. Read the complete article to know more about the total AIIMS in India, courses offered by them, fees, and the number of seats in each programme.

AIIMS in India was established under the Act of Parliament, 1956. The functions and objectives of the institute were defined in this act, thus giving it an autonomous status. Later in 2003, the Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana (PMSSY) planted the seeds for the expansion of the most esteemed medical institution in India and led to the establishment of other AIIMS campuses.
